title: Malware Response Runbook
prompt: Arrange the malware remediation steps in the recommended order after confirming an infection on a Windows host.

items.label: Schedule scans and run Windows Update

explanation: CompTIA's order: verify, isolate, prevent reinfection (disable restore + update definitions), remediate, schedule follow-up updates, re-enable restore, and finish with user education.

title: Pick the Right Windows Utility
prompt: Match each troubleshooting task to the native Windows tool you should launch.

pairs.left: View real-time CPU, memory, disk, and network utilization while the user reproduces the slowdown.
Log system performance counters for 24 hours to capture intermittent spikes.
Check the laptop's BIOS revision plus Windows build to compare against a known-good list.
Automate a daily post-remediation run of Windows Update.

explanation: Practice Exam B focuses on pairing Task Manager, Performance Monitor, System Information, and Task Scheduler with those exact tasks.

title: Script the Right Workflow
prompt: Select the scripting language best suited for each automation request.

pairs.left: Create an Active Directory user and add them to multiple security groups during onboarding.
Update a public web page so it displays the visitor's country flag using their IP address.
Back up log files across Windows, Linux, and macOS endpoints with one cross-platform script.
Automate an Excel workbook to convert all imperial measurements to metric.
Restart four load-balanced Linux web servers sequentially each night.

explanation: These pairings mirror the scripting PBQ in Practice Exam B.

title: Linux Ops Toolkit
prompt: Match each administrative task to the Linux command you'd run.

pairs.left: Install a third-party graphics package on a Fedora workstation.
Verify that the workstation still has free disk space before the install.
Edit the text-based configuration file that ships with the new tool.
Scan the filesystem for orphaned blocks after a crash.
Find every occurrence of the word 'denied' inside /var/log/auth.log.

explanation: This mirrors the Linux PBQ pattern from Practice Exam C.

title: Map the Engineering Share
prompt: From a Windows terminal, map drive letter G: to \\core-svr\eng-data and make the mapping persistent across reboots.
explanation: The CompTIA PBQs expect NET USE with the drive letter first, then the UNC path and persistence flag.

title: Verify DNS Resolution
prompt: Investigate why users cannot reach app.examplelab.net by querying your default DNS server for that hostname.
explanation: Running NSLOOKUP against the FQDN identifies the IP being blocked.
